title: Logger can send too-long message to syslog
body:
This is not a critical bug.

Need to handle situations when a message sent to the log is very long and the logger throws an exception:

```
--- Logging error ---
Traceback (most recent call last):

    self.socket.send(msg)
OSError: [Errno 90] Message too long

    self._bootstrap_inner()

    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/threading.py", line 864, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pscheduler/worker.py", line 68, in __run
    result = self.worker()

    self.__run()
  File "/local/mfeit/pscheduler/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/archiver.raw", line 863, in __run

  File "/local/mfeit/pscheduler/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/archiver.raw", line 477, in __call__

  File "/local/mfeit/pscheduler/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/archiver.raw", line 344, in __call__

  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pscheduler/log.py", line 346, in debug

    logger.log(level, line)
Arguments: ()

title: Traceroute tool doesn't sudo for TCP probes
body: Title says it all.  Should be a quick fix.

title: Archiver Freezes Up
body:
Otto has been seeing the archiver on one of his systems jam up after about 20 hours of operation.  WLCG may be having the same problem.  Otto is using the RMQ and HTTP archivers.  WLCG is, too.

Based on the debug logs, it looks like the archiver is reaching its maximum parallel archivings and stopping  because archivings aren't finishing.  Need to determine why that is.


Known things to do:

- [ ] Put a cap on the amount of time a worker thread should spend waiting for a process and fail nicely if none can be had.  (See [code](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/9d67be3b6b0530a6579c02fa1712b7337bc3e9be/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/archiver.raw#L289).)

- [ ] Probably need more debug in the process pools to see why they're not reporting on unfinished archivings or the program isn't coming to terms with processes dying if that's what's happening.

- [ ] Should mark archivings in the database as underway and not do the TTL sweep on them when in that state.  Let the archiver make a positive determination of how things went.

- [ ] `StreamingJSONProgram`'s `_roundtrip()` method could stand to have some kind of reasonably-long timeout provided by the instantiator in case the called program never  returns.

title: Redact system info from iperf3 diagnostics
body: Adjust the iperf3 plugin so it removes the `system_info` field from the output before it goes into the diagnostics.

title: Archiver keeps processes around too long
body: Under load, the archiver process pools appear to keep more `archive` methods around than are needed.  This might have to do with the way processes are selected.  Maybe try a most-recently-used approach.

title: Ping parser doesn't handle full loss correctly
body:
Don't try to calculate based on `min` if there isn't one:

```
  Tool failed: Traceback (most recent call last):
    File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/classes/tool/ping/run", line 274, in <module>
      parsed_results = pscheduler.parse_ping(stdout, count)
    File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pscheduler/ping.py", line 162, in parse_ping
      datetime.timedelta(seconds=float(min)/1000.0) ),
  UnboundLocalError: local variable 'min' referenced before assignment
```

title: Schedule command crashes when verbose
body:
```
$ pscheduler schedule --verbose

... Much output ...

2022-01-27T15:01:38Z - 2022-01-27T15:01:54Z (Non-Starter)
Non-Start Reason:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/commands/schedule", line 298, in <module>
    run.get("errors", "Unspecified error").strip(),
AttributeError: 'dict' object has no attribute 'strip'
```

The raw run data in the server looks right; it looks like the `schedule` endpoint in the API is passing back the wrong thing.  

Code [here](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/4bd02845003d6f38fd0cd0dd76c557572f33272b/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/api-server/pschedulerapiserver/schedule.py#L143) needs to be checked to make column indexes match the query.

title: DNS plugin times out when the first DNS resolver is unavailable
body:
When the first one of the DNS resolvers from `/etc/resolv.conf` is unavailable, the pScheduler DNS plugin doesn't seem to be able to use any other working one.  Running a task always results in a timeout.  Changing the order of resolvers in `/etc/resolv.conf` makes the DNS tasks work again.

Will https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/issues/855 solve this behaviour?

title: Nuttcp burst mode exceeds bandwidth
body: Need to not use burst mode if a bandwidth curb is in effect.

title: Crashing happening with weird timestamp
pscheduler issues with iperf2
body:
The use of pscheduler and iperf2 throughput options seems to have a few rough cases. 

(0) pscheduler doesn't report retransmits and current window when used with iperf2. Yet, this could be easily retrieved the output of iperf.  Ofc, iperf would have to be passed the option -e for enhanced output

(1) pscheduler frequently reports an error when used with iperf2 and option  --interval. If that option is remove the request runs to completion.


 pscheduler task  --tool iperf2 throughput --source dest.host --dest source.host -t 10 --interval=10

Waiting for result...

Problem fetching results: Failed to format result: At /summary/summary: None is not of type 'object'


$ pscheduler version|grep iperf
pscheduler-tool-bwctliperf2             4.4.1-1.el7
pspscheduler task --tool iperf2 throughput --source ps2.netherlight.net --dest 200.0.206.71 -t 60 -i 60 -P 6 cheduler-tool-bwctliperf3             4.4.1-1.el7
pscheduler-tool-iperf2                  4.4.1-1.el7
pscheduler-tool-iperf3                  4.4.1-1.el7

title: Nmapreach shows broadcast as up
body:
The network's broadcast address should be excluded when checking for upness.

More debug and diagnostics would be nice, too.

body:
Seen at SC:

```
2021/11/12 11:09:43 WARN pid=28122 prog=perfSONAR_PS::PSConfig::PScheduler::Agent::_run_end line=231 guid=AC414C4C-43E3-11EC-8ED1-678183584AF3 msg=Problem adding test netreach, continuing with rest of config: INTERNAL SERVER ERROR: Unable to validate test spec: Traceback (most recent call last):

    valid, message = spec_is_valid(json)
  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/classes/test/netreach/validate.py", line 88, in spec_is_valid
    network = ipaddress.ip_network(str(json["network"]))
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.6/ipaddress.py", line 84, in ip_network
    address)
ValueError: 'None' does not appear to be an IPv4 or IPv6 network
```

Need to properly reject null values for the network field.

title: Clock test needs a source-node parameter
body: Title says it all.

title: Background-multis get stuck in on-deck state
body:
@grigutis observed a bgmulti task that got into the on-deck state but never started running.

The maintenance routine is the culprit:

```
            -- Non-background-multi runs pending on deck after start times
            -- were missed
            ( test.scheduling_class <> scheduling_class_background_multi()
              AND lower(times) < straggle_time
              AND run.state IN ( run_state_pending(), run_state_on_deck() )
            )

            OR

            -- Background-multi runs that passed their end time
            ( test.scheduling_class = scheduling_class_background_multi()
              AND upper(times) < straggle_time_bg_multi
              AND run.state IN ( run_state_pending(), run_state_on_deck() )
            )
```

Straggling bgmultis should be knocked back into the `pending` state if they don't start so the runner will pick them back up and try again.

title: Postgresql-init doesn't fail gracefully with partial 9.5 present
body:
The `upgrade-postgresql` script in `postgresql-init` [attempts](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/7f8af2719da79d7b64a962013dae4ef96f1669ab/postgresql-init/postgresql-init/upgrade-postgresql.raw#L86) to do some things with the old 9.5 packages when they're present.

The line linked can be removed since 4.3.x is no longer supported.

title: timestamp_parsed() returns the wrong type
body:
The `timestamp_parsed()` function in the jq library returns strings when it should return integers.

Putting this at the end of the pipeline should fix it:
```
  | with_entries(tonumber)
```

**Release Notes:**

The return values of the jq library's `timestamp_parsed()` function have been changed to return numbers instead of strings.

title: Iperf3 client/server functions should return rather than exit
Stray iperf3 servers can cause problems
body:
Some installations of 4.4.0 are seeing occasions where the iperf3 server process is becoming orphaned and remaining up.  This causes problems because it's expecting different authorization than ones that are trying to run and failing because the port is occupied.

- [x] Write some code into the tool plugin that hunts down and kills old server processes that have been orphaned.

title: Iperf3 plugin throws exception with loopback
body:
When running in loopback mode, the `iperf3` plugin throws an exception:

```
$ pscheduler task throughput --loopback --dest 127.0.0.1
Submitting task...
Task URL:
https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/42e6449f-69b4-4cd3-a67d-05d59fc6244d
Running with tool 'iperf3'
Fetching first run...

Next scheduled run:
https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/42e6449f-69b4-4cd3-a67d-05d59fc6244d/runs/f39745e2-597a-47db-b7b8-5f0f0789d5b2
Starts 2021-05-28T14:45:46Z (~2 seconds)
Ends   2021-05-28T14:46:05Z (~18 seconds)
Waiting for result...

Run failed.

Diagnostics:


Limit system diagnostics for this run:
  No limits were applied

No further runs scheduled.
```

From the log:
```
May 28 14:46:56 psdev1 journal: runner INFO     13: Running https://127.0.0.1/pscheduler/tasks/1bffef10-df01-4e86-a2b3-8589bb585979/runs/9dac6449-b705-4372-b7b6-08d45c11a823
May 28 14:46:56 psdev1 journal: runner INFO     13: With iperf3: throughput --source 127.0.0.1 --dest 127.0.0.1 --loopback
May 28 14:46:56 psdev1 journal: tool-iperf3/run ERROR    Exception list index out of range
May 28 14:46:56 psdev1 journal: runner INFO     13: Run succeeded.

```

From the API:
```
curl -sk https://127.0.0.1/pscheduler/tasks/1bffef10-df01-4e86-a2b3-8589bb585979/runs/9dac6449-b705-4372-b7b6-08d45c11a823 | jq .errors
"Exception in thread Thread-1:\nTraceback (most recent call last):\n"
```

A few things need to be done:

- [x] Determine what's causing `Thread-1` to throw the exception.
- [x] Adjust the code that creates the thread to run the target method in an exception-safe way.  ([Example](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/a6e9cedaa99a883a44c83ae41fd9e2c294f5398d/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/archiver.raw#L549))
- [x] Adjust the final catch at the bottom of the program to call `log.exception()`, which will properly format and log the exception.  The result should probably get that properly-formatted error in it as well.

title: Single-ended, reverse nuttcp test is failing due to missing "-r" option on client host
body:
I realize this is one of those rare use cases but I have a situation where I need to run a single-ended nuttcp test and reverse the direction of the test flow.  It works fine when I run nuttcp standalone but when I tried it with pscheduler it fails because pscheduler doesn’t set the “-r” nuttcp receiver flag on the client host receiving the reverse test flow. In order to get nuttcp reverse test flows to work both the “-r” and “-F” CLI options are required.  FWIW, it works fine when transmitting tests.

----- pscheduler nuttcp with reverse test flow fails:
> pscheduler task --tool nuttcp throughput --dest xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx --single-ended  --single-ended-port=5000 --reverse
 
The nuttcp command that pscheduler generates (from pscheduler.log) leaves out the “-r” receiver option which causes the failure
/usr/bin/nuttcp -p 5101 -P 5000 -T 10 -F xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
 
 
----- running the same pscheduler nuttcp command as above via the CLI but with the receiver flag  (-r) set is successful:
> /usr/bin/nuttcp -p 5101 -P 5000 -T 10 -r -F xxx.xxx.xxx.xxx
   51.3111 MB /  10.16 sec =   42.3535 Mbps 0 %TX 3 %RX 0 retrans 9.81 msRTT

title: Archiver not dropping internal workers
body:
The archiver is, on some systems, not consistently dropping worker IDs from the set of workers believed to be running.

There's an open TODO in the source about using `ThreadSafeSet`.

title: Powstream tool underestimates run time
body: The powstream tool returns its duration as exactly the test length, which doesn't account for startup and shutdown time and causes the runner to get a timeout.  Add some slop.

title: Survive inability to make a thread.
body: The daemons that use threads crash when they aren't able to create new threads.  This should be caught and dealt with so work being done by existing threads isn't interrupted.

title: file path issues... systemd params problem
body:
Hi Mark

Problem are the bad file path statements in the Systemd pscheduler-scheduler config:
version is: pscheduler-server.noarch                          4.4.0-0.a1.0.el

specifically this line:
[root@r72 ~]# grep "/run/pscheduler-server/pscheduler/scheduler/options" /usr/lib/systemd/system/pscheduler-scheduler.service
```
ExecStartPre=-/bin/sh -c "if [ -r /etc/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler/conf ]; then opts=$(sed -e 's/#.*$//' /etc/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler/conf); echo OPTIONS=$opts > /run/pscheduler-server/pscheduler/scheduler/options; chown pscheduler:pscheduler /run/pscheduler-server/scheduler/options; fi"
```
The folder for the options file doesn't exist:
[root@r72 ~]# ll /etc/pscheduler/daemons/
total 16
-rw-------. 1 pscheduler pscheduler 160 Nov 10 21:08 archiver.conf
-rw-------. 1 pscheduler pscheduler 158 Nov 10 21:08 runner.conf
-rw-------. 1 pscheduler pscheduler 208 Mar 15 14:54 **scheduler.conf**
-rw-------. 1 pscheduler pscheduler 158 Nov 10 21:08 ticker.conf


the file scheduler.conf is not referenced

on top there is a file which is referenced by systemd config (see above), but is not present, therefore leads to errors in service start.
```
Mar 15 15:31:24 r72 systemd: Starting pScheduler server - scheduler...
Mar 15 15:31:24 r72 sh: /bin/sh: /run/pscheduler-server/pscheduler/scheduler/options: No such file or directory
Mar 15 15:31:24 r72 sh: chown: cannot access вЂ/run/pscheduler-server/scheduler/optionsвЂ™: No such file or directory
```

title: Backport PyJQ 2.4 into next bugfix
body:
2.3 has a memory leak.

----

From: John Thiltges <jthiltges@unl.edu>

Hi Mark and Andy,

I've hopefully made some progress on diagnosing the memory leak of the archiver. Signs point to pyjq, and it reproducibly leaks each time a transform is run. Updating pyjq to >= v2.4 seems to fix it.

I'd guess this is the upstream commit that fixes the issue (tagged in v2.4.0):

Fix memory leak in jv_to_pyobj list and dict cases
https://github.com/doloopwhile/pyjq/commit/21193f56635e371aa58d8c118d901648540f63bf

Regards,
John

Script to reproduce:

```
import pyjq
import pprint

for i in range(0, 2):

    script = pyjq.compile(
        '.headers.x_ps_observer = "hcc-ps01.unl.edu"', # filter_spec
        {}                                              # args
    )

    result = script.all(
        {
            'id': '12345678',
        }
    )[0]
    pprint.pprint(result)
```

Valgrind results show the leaked memory increasing with each pyjq pass. (And note that the leak is much larger when transforming a real task. Around 4.5k each.)

```
1 pass:

==53063== LEAK SUMMARY:
==53063==    definitely lost: 460 bytes in 4 blocks

2 passes:

==53065== LEAK SUMMARY:
==53065==    definitely lost: 920 bytes in 8 blocks
```

title: Catch attempts to post task with invalid or unsupported tool.
body:
`POST`s to the API's `/tasks` endpoint requesting a tool that exists but can't run the task causes the database's `api_task_post()` to throw an exception.  This condition should be caught in the API during the tool selection process.

```
pscheduler-api ERROR    Exception: psycopg2.InternalError: Tool "bwctltraceroute" is not available

pscheduler-api ERROR      File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/flask/app.py", line 1936, in dispatch_request
pscheduler-api ERROR        return self.view_functions[rule.endpoint](**req.view_args)
pscheduler-api ERROR      File "/var/www/pscheduler-server/pschedulerapiserver/tasks.py", line 477, in tasks
pscheduler-api ERROR        task.get("priority", None), diags], onerow=True)
pscheduler-api ERROR      File "/var/www/pscheduler-server/pschedulerapiserver/dbcursor.py", line 112, in dbcursor_query
pscheduler-api ERROR        raise ex
pscheduler-api ERROR      File "/var/www/pscheduler-server/pschedulerapiserver/dbcursor.py", line 97, in dbcursor_query
pscheduler-api ERROR        cursor.execute(query, args)
pscheduler-api ERROR    psycopg2.InternalError: Tool "bwctltraceroute" is not available
```

The API should kick a bad request back to the caller rather than a 500 since this isn't an internal problem.

title: ExpiringSet abuses dictionary
body:
The `ExpiringSet` class in the library tries to delete items in its dictionary while still iterating over them.

Fix that by collecting a list of items to be purged and then deleting them.

title: Fix debugging in runner
body: The runner's worker method needs to use the debug method (as in the archiver and others) consistently.  It's a mix of that and calls to `self.log.debug`, and the latter doesn't show correctly when the per-task debug switch is on.

title: Daemon options files for systemd services are not loaded
body:
pScheduler daemons have options files such as `/etc/pscheduler/daemons/archiver.conf` to allow additional runtime flags to be set, such as `--debug`. But, the options files are apparently not loaded due to a few issues:

- The systemd configuration looks in `/etc/pscheduler/daemons/archiver/conf` instead of `archiver.conf`
- ExecStartPre attempts to write the options to a non-existent directory (`/run/pscheduler-server/pscheduler/archiver/options` rather than `/run/pscheduler-server/archiver/options`)

After fixing those minor issues in `service-template.raw` I ran into other issues:

- The options don't get into the `$OPTIONS` environment variable
- Trying to set `EnvironmentFile=/run/pscheduler-server/archiver/options` caused systemd to fail, since the environment file doesn't exist until it's created by `ExecStartPre`

The easiest way I found to set daemon options was to create an override. For example, `systemctl edit pscheduler-archiver.service` and the following:

```
[Service]
Environment=OPTIONS=--debug
```

title: Problems with HTTP Tools
body:
Szymon observed the following:

```
pscheduler task --debug-pscheduler --tool psurl http --url=www.geant.org
Submitting task...
Task URL:
https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/fd545cc6-1f51-4e97-a9a8-1f5723485d58
Running with tool 'psurl'
Fetching first run...

Next scheduled run:
https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/fd545cc6-1f51-4e97-a9a8-1f5723485d58/runs/43a75b3e-73a9-413e-bce9-0decdb6928ad
Starts 2020-12-04T17:15:07Z (~3 seconds)
Ends   2020-12-04T17:15:14Z (~6 seconds)
Waiting for result...

Problem fetching results: Failed to format result: At /: Additional properties are not allowed ('status' was unexpected)
```

I added the `--tool` switch because my system wants to default to `curl` instead of `psurl`.  The server at GÉANT is returning a 301; the tool should not be treating that as success unless explicitly requested and the result formatter shouldn't be barfing on it.

title: Fix DNS Lookups in Identifier Tests
body:
Tests in `python-pscheduler/pscheduler/tests/limitprocessor_identifier_ipreversedns_test.py` depend on certain host names at I2 and ESnet.

See if there's a better way to do this.

title: Duplicate file in logrotate
body:
Installing 4.3.0's `python3-pscheduler` leaves 4.2.4's `/etc/logrotate.d/python-pscheduler` in place and logrotate complains about the duplicate of `/var/log/pscheduler/pscheduler.log`.

Either obsolete `python-pscheduler` (may be dangerous) or patch its logrotate file to comment out the contents.

title: Fix conversion bug in twping
body: The `run` method of the twping tool mis-parses the start time as a duration.  Fix that.

title: Scheduler May Be Leaking FDs
body:
@igarny Has been having trouble with one of his systems running out of FDs.  Last night he passed this along:

```
sudo lsof -u pscheduler | awk '$4 ~ /[0-9]+[rwu -].*/{p[$1"\t"$2"\t"$3]=p[$1"\t"$2"\t"$3]+1}END{for (i in p) print p[i],i}' | sort -n | tail
20 httpd        169224  pscheduler
20 httpd        233104  pscheduler
20 httpd        35603   pscheduler
20 httpd        62208   pscheduler
20 httpd        83103   pscheduler
20 httpd        8491    pscheduler
22 httpd        113741  pscheduler
26 httpd        189507  pscheduler
107 runner      3342    pscheduler
4094 scheduler  46908   pscheduler
```

Restarting the scheduler resets the problem, but it appears that the FD count grows by at least one per hour.  Need to investigate whether something in the scheduler is leaking a FD.

This is from the test bed, where the scheduler has been running since July 8:
```
[root@tb-el7-prod ~]# lsof -u pscheduler | awk '$4 ~ /[0-9]+[rwu -].*/{p[$1"\t"$2"\t"$3]=p[$1"\t"$2"\t"$3]+1}END{for (i in p) print p[i],i}' | sort -n | tail

root     15164 14825  0 12:40 pts/0    00:00:00 grep -F --color=auto /scheduler

title: PostgreSQL 9-10 Upgrade Fails
body:
PostgreSQL Upgrades of existing systems are failing with this message:

```
Your installation references loadable libraries that are missing from the
new installation.  You can add these libraries to the new installation,
or remove the functions using them from the old installation.  A list of
problem libraries is in the file:
    loadable_libraries.txt
```

`loadable_libraries.txt` contains:
```
could not load library "$libdir/dblink": ERROR:  could not access file "$libdir/dblink": No such file or directory
could not load library "$libdir/pgcrypto": ERROR:  could not access file "$libdir/pgcrypto": No such file or directory
could not load library "$libdir/plpython2": ERROR:  could not access file "$libdir/plpython2": No such file or directory
```

It does seem to produce a runnable system in the end; still need to fix it.

title: Runs non-starting close to the horizon
body:
See title.  This problem has been figured out already; this ticket is just to document it.

This is a trimmed-down version of the log with commentary.

```
14:56:43 1414: New thread for task f2415ffe-b896-4519-b15b-cf3fc93eb074 at 2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00
```

Current time is 2020-09-02 14:56:43+00:00
Schedule horizon is 2020-09-03 14:56:43+00:00
Ideal start time is 2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00 -- Four seconds from the horizon

```
14:56:43 1414: ANYTIME TASK f2415ffe-b896-4519-b15b-cf3fc93eb074, 121 runs, try 2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00
14:56:43 1414: Trying to schedule f2415ffe-b896-4519-b15b-cf3fc93eb074 for 2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00

14:56:43 1414: Bind is None
14:56:43 1414: Participant list is ['tb-el7-minor.ps.dev.internet2.edu']
14:56:43 1414: Binding from None

14:56:43 1414: Ranges: [R(2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00..2020-09-03 15:02:17+00:00)]

14:56:43 1414: Ranges in common: [R(2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00..2020-09-03 15:02:17+00:00)]
```
At this point, the start of the range is still within the horizon.

```
14:56:43 1414: Slipping randomly up to 0:05:00
14:56:43 1414: 300 increments, picked 116
14:56:43 1414: Selected range R(2020-09-03 14:56:39+00:00..2020-09-03 15:02:17+00:00)
14:56:43 1414: Using a slip offset of 0:01:56
```

The slip puts the start time over the horizon.  We need to disqualify tasks with slip from being scheduled within `slip` of the scheduling horizon.  The scheduler will pick it up later.

Need to either detect master runs (better) or proceed to the next one.

Check all two-participant tests for this problem.

title: Locking of run table causes congestion
body:
Marian reports that `psb01-gva.cern.ch` is showing an increasing number of non-starters and has been since the first of the year.

The problem looks to be processes getting jammed up waiting for locks on the `run` table to clear, likely these two, which are the only places we do any explicit locking:

https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/e59d262749e494694745b04724afe6cd4263af6d/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/database/run.sql#L368

https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/e59d262749e494694745b04724afe6cd4263af6d/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/database/run.sql#L889

This is probably too conservative, although I'm at a loss about how to prevent runs for two tasks being scheduled into the same slot.

title: Scheduler doesn't pick up on long-duration tasks
body:
From the mailing list, Murilo Vetter writes:

> When trying to schedule a long period test (like 1 day = 86400 sec), it is failing to schedule.
> The maximum amount of time that it passes is 86090 seconds, missing 310 seconds.
> Is there some reason to occur this?
> 
> **IT IS WORKING:**
> pscheduler task throughput -s 10.39.2.2 -d 10.39.2.6 -u -t 86090 -b 100m -l 1472
> ...
> Starts 2019-11-21T07:13:46-05 (~7 seconds)
> Ends   2019-11-22T07:08:45-05 (~86098 seconds)
> 
> **IT IS NOT WORKING:**
> pscheduler task throughput -s 10.39.2.2 -d 10.39.2.6 -u -t 86091 -b 100m -l 1472
> ...
> No runs scheduled for this task.

Debug on the scheduler shows that it picks up on the task change but not does not retrieve it in the list of tasks that need scheduling.

The likely cause is the query behind the `schedule_runs_to_schedule` view filtering these tasks out.

-----

Additional input:


> Thanks for the reply. One thing that we are having trouble too is that when trying to schedule long time period test, like:
> 
> --
> Nov 27 08:12:25 90bfb2bfc852 runner INFO     14: With iperf3: throughput --bandwidth 100000000 --duration PT23H50M --source 10.39.2.2 --dest 10.39.2.6 --interval PT1M --buffer-length 1472 --udp
> Nov 28 02:12:06 90bfb2bfc852 runner INFO     14: Run succeeded.
> --
> 
> It does not show the result of the test as expected:
> 
> # pscheduler schedule
> 2019-11-27T06:12:15-05:00 - 2019-11-28T06:02:21-05:00  (Running)
> rtt --count 85800 --dest 10.39.2.6 --source 10.39.2.2 (Run with tool 'ping')
> https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/8e410289-449a-4ada-824d-a96b5d338ebc/runs/84df8ac8-a5e4-4053-b9af-3d73a5c36d13
> 
> 
> 2019-11-27T06:12:25-05:00 - 2019-11-28T06:02:34-05:00  (Cleanup)
> throughput --bandwidth 100000000 --duration PT23H50M --source 10.39.2.2 --dest 10.39.2.6 --interval PT1M --buffer-length 1472 --udp (Run with tool 'iperf3')
> https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/2813165e-d957-4dc5-a5c3-67cb8f0ed608/runs/755d77d7-44fa-4ca3-810b-8321db262b4c
> 
> # pscheduler result https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/2813165e-d957-4dc5-a5c3-67cb8f0ed608/runs/755d77d7-44fa-4ca3-810b-8321db262b4c
> 2019-11-27T06:12:25-05 on 10.39.2.2 and 10.39.2.6 with iperf3:
> 
> throughput --bandwidth 100000000 --duration PT23H50M --source 10.39.2.2 --dest 10.39.2.6 --interval PT1M --buffer-length 1472 --udp
> 
> Run has not completed.
> 
> Is something that we are missing? We know that it is working because looking at router interfaces we see expected traffic.
>

title: `task trace --sendwait` not working as documented
body:
v4.2.1 on CentOS 7

`pscheduler task trace --help` gives the following example of the `--sendwait` option:

```
  task trace --sendwait PT3S --dest www.example.com
      Wait 3 seconds between probes
```

title: pscheduler TASK output states PRIORITY assignment, which is wrong
body: In principle *pscheduler task* should not report 'priority' assignments, since these are not valid at the time of task coordination. priorities are properties of runs

title: DNS test "--nameserver" parameter not working
body:
The dns test not sends queries to that specific server, which passed as argument in "--nameserver" parameter.
For example, this IP address is not a DNS server, but command below will still work:
pscheduler task dns --query cert.ge --record mx --nameserver=217.147.224.29

title: Test netreach with --network being a /32 or a /31
body:
When asking pscheduler to perform a ``netreach`` test with a **/32** IPv4 network you get a python error:
```
antoine^2@d9:)~$ pscheduler task netreach --network 1.1.1.1/32
Submitting task...
Failed to post task: Unable to validate test spec: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/pscheduler/commands/../classes/test/netreach/spec-is-valid", line 20, in <module>
    valid, message = spec_is_valid(json)
  File "/usr/lib/pscheduler/classes/test/netreach/validate.py", line 93, in spec_is_valid
    gateway = network[1]  # A dummy to make the other tests pass.
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/ipaddress.py", line 762, in __getitem__
    raise IndexError('address out of range')
IndexError: address out of range
```

Asking for a **/31** raises a different kind of issue:
```
antoine^2@d9:(~$ pscheduler task netreach --network 192.168.0.128/31
Submitting task...
Failed to post task: Invalid test specification: Gateway cannot be the network or broadcast address.
```

Their IPv6 counterpart **/128** and **/127** are probably behaving similarily.

title: idle test needs slop time
body: snooze and sleep need slop

title: Check host resolution in tool run methods for flaws
body: In #886, it was observed that the ping tool's `run` method was passing `None` into some of the IP-releated library functions when things didn't resolve.  That was causing the tool to throw exceptions in some cases.  It was corrected in ping, but needs to be investigated in other tools, especially those that can do v4/v6 or involve multiple hosts.

Should probably do an upsert in case any of the daemons are already running.

title: Bad state transitions around canceled runs
body:
Some systems are showing state transition errors on runs of tasks that were canceled.

The transition is usually 11 (Canceled) to 5 (FInished) or 8 (Failed), suggesting that cancellation is affecting runs already in the pipeline to be run.  Also saw a 5 to 11.

Consider making cancellation work only on pending runs if it doesn't already or having the runner include a `WHERE` clause in the update that does nothing for runs that were canceled.

title: Normalize DNS Resolution Behavior
body:
Make the family order of DNS resolution in the pScheduler library follow [RFC6724](https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc6724.html) rather than being hard-wired for 4 then 6.

Check everything that calls these functions to make sure nothing's going to break.

title: Watch prints messages in non-text formats
body:
With the `--format` switch in effect, `watch` spits out "No further runs..." when it's finished.

Fix that.  Nominally, if the switch is in effect, the output should be _only_ the test result.  Should probably also exit after the first result since streamed JSON wouldn't make a lot of sense.

title: Fix Function Declarations in Database
body:
One of the database functions changed prototype between 4.1.6 and 4.2.0 and causes upgrade problems.

Need to go through the database and make sure there's a call to `drop_function_all` for every function declaration.

title: Iperf3 plugin binds badly for UDP

milestone.title: hackathon-20190520
milestone.description: Milestone to tag issue for the May 20th, 2019 hackathon in Bloomington, IN

body:
UofM has having problems running UDP tests from the outside into NATted (actual 1:1 NAT, not PAT) AWS instances.  The arrangement is like this:

    (UMICH HOST) 1.2.3.4 -----> 3.4.5.6 (NAT) 10.0.0.99 -----> 10.0.0.1 (AWS INSTANCE)

Because of the behavior described in https://github.com/esnet/iperf/issues/505, Dan included [code to bind explicitly to the destination](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/de57f48f3a37bd3bea9be116923db430d98641c6/pscheduler-tool-iperf3/iperf3/run#L307) when running UDP tests.  This doesn't work in the NAT case because it will try to bind to the nonexistant 3.4.5.6 address.

Need to find out why iperf3 behaves as it does and, if it can be fixed to bind to any address, adjust the plugin accordingly.

Talked to Bruce about it an opened this issue against iperf3:  https://github.com/esnet/iperf/issues/860

title: Clock checks aren't robust
body:
Shawn McKee observed the following:
```
# pscheduler troubleshoot --host perfsonar-ps.ndgf.org --stats
Performing basic troubleshooting of perfsonar-ps.ndgf.org.

 Checking path MTU... 1500+

 Checking clock... Failed.
Unable to fetch clock state: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'synchronized'

Looks like the call to `ntp_adjtime()` in `clockstate.py` isn't sufficiently guarded against returns of `None`.  Fix that.

body:
When running with the 4.2.0 code and the toolkit's stock limit configuration, the rewriter fails:

```

Submitting task...

The 'pscheduler troubleshoot' command may be of use in problem
diagnosis. 'pscheduler troubleshoot --help' for more information.
```

I trimmed the rewrite clause down to nothing and it still fails, so the problem is likely in the rewriter Python module.

body:
The `disk-to-disk` test doesn't have support in `cli-to-spec` that will allow specification of the host where the task is to be run.  This causes failures when the lead participant's pScheduler is listening on an alternate port.

(Should be an easy fix.)

title: Trace tools set dest as lead participant if source is not reachable
body:
I'll start off by saying this is an artifact of the bwctl backward compatibility. Take the output below as an example:

```
# pscheduler task trace --source 154.114.10.164 --dest 141.211.176.232
Submitting task...
Task URL:
https://141.211.176.232/pscheduler/tasks/91889aa3-f5d0-4041-8d32-a1829b1094ae
Running with tool 'traceroute'
Fetching first run...

Next scheduled run:
https://141.211.176.232/pscheduler/tasks/91889aa3-f5d0-4041-8d32-a1829b1094ae/runs/b91e810e-9fd3-4640-948b-5a7b440308f9
Starts 2018-11-30T20:34:31Z (~7 seconds)
Ends   2018-11-30T20:34:39Z (~7 seconds)
Waiting for result...

Run failed.

Limit system diagnostics:
  Hints:
    requester: 198.128.151.25
    server: 141.211.176.232
  Identified as everybody
  Classified as everybody, default
  Application: Defaults
    Group 1: Limit 'innocuous-tests' passed
    Group 1: Limit 'rtt-default' failed: Test is not 'rtt'
    Group 1: Limit 'throughput-default' failed: Test is not 'throughput'
    Group 1: Want any, 1/3 passed, 2/3 failed: PASS
    Application PASSES
  Proposal meets limits


Diagnostics from 141.211.176.232:
    traceroute -q 1 -4 -s 154.114.10.164 -N 30 -n 141.211.176.232

Error from 141.211.176.232:
    
    bind: Cannot assign requested address
    

No further runs scheduled.
```

Note that the `dest` is set as the lead which is incorrect and leads to an incorrect attempt to bind on the `dest` host using the `source` address. The problem is that the `trace`test's `participants` call returns only one participant  and the `traceroute` tool does not short-circuit in `can-run` if there is only 1 participant. The reason it does not short-circuit is that it expects `bwctltraceroute` with a higher tool priority to handle any one participant cases. Since `bwctltraceroute` is not installed by default anymore, tests like this make there way to the trace tool. 

We need to discuss whether we think we should check the participants in the tools, or if we we should wait until BWTL support is dropped in February at which point we should update `participants` to always return two participants.

title: JSON validator for IPv6 CIDRs is wrong
body:
The JSON validator for IPv6 CIDRs treats `dead:beef/64` as valid when the proper notation is `dead:beef::/64`.

This was worked around in the code that implemented #703, so that should be adjusted accordingly.

title: Archive failure debugging
body:
When archiving is failing, it's difficult to track down the cause. There are a few issues that contribute to this. By the way, these issues all were experienced with the esmond archiver, but I suspect some/all of them are applicable to archiving in general.

- [ ] 1. Archive failures do not always follow the retry options; in the situation we saw today, failed archivings were retried again and again, causing a long backlog. It did not appear it was going to clear. It's also not clear to me whether these would have expired at some point, but we had a backlog of >1000, interfering with other tests.
- [ ] 2. Archive errors (`diags`) are not populated until the archiver gives up on that archiving
- [ ] 3. Running tests with the `--debug` flag does nothing to increase verbosity when archiving

Number 1 and 2 above are especially problematic in that you *never* get the `diags` field populated.

Here's an example of something being retried again and again:
```

```


from that same task:
```
               "retry-policy": [
                    {
                        "attempts": 1,
                        "wait": "PT60S"
                    },
                    {
                        "attempts": 1,
                        "wait": "PT120S"
                    }
```

I would expect this to archive, retry once after 60s, and again after 120s, but instead it retries dozens of times at once, repeating over and over, with `last_attempt` and `diags` never getting set.

title: Archiving fails if reference is not set
body:
When creating a task, if you don't specify anything for the `reference` field, which is supposed to be optional, archiving fails, in a way that is difficult to detect the cause.

Once you set `reference` to something (we just used dummy data, I think even an empty object `{}` would have worked), archiving works as expected. 

Note that we ran into this issue using our custom scheduler, not psconfig.

Apparently `psconfig` supplies a `reference` field, which is why others have not had this issue.

title: Limit Diags not Finding Imports
body:
The `limit-diags` command doesn't find the files in `/usr/lib/jq/pscheduler` for import:

```
% pscheduler limit-diags --hints '{ "requester": "9.9.9.9", "server": "8.8.8.8" }' --config ./pscheduler_limits.conf ~/hole/task
Unable to read limit configuration: jq: error: module not found: pscheduler/iso8601

jq: 1 compile error
```

The limit processor in the API server works just fine.

title: Limit system sees ::1 for all requesters.
body:
Pete Siemsen [writes on the user list](https://lists.internet2.edu/sympa/arc/perfsonar-user/2018-09/msg00088.html):

 > What might explain the following:
```
perfsonar-1850$  pscheduler task throughput -t 30 -d 158.142.6.250
Submitting task...
Unable to post task: Task forbidden by limits:
Hints:
  requester: ::1
  server: ::1
Made no identifications.
The 'pscheduler troubleshoot' command may be of use in problem
diagnosis. 'pscheduler troubleshoot --help' for more information.
```
 > I think the above "pscheduler" command means "Do a 30-second throughput test to 158.142.6.250". I can execute that command successfully on another perfSONAR machine at my site. The working machine is running 4.0.2 on CentOS 6.10. The failing machine is running 4.1.2 on CentOS 7.5. The failing machine is a fresh install - it has net yet had a working test configured.

 > I'm suspicious of the "::1" in the above output. Looks like the requester and server are both the IPv6 localhost? Huh? Any clue appreciated.

Need to look into why the requester is coming up localhost.  It shouldn't be, so maybe this is the result of a change in Apache in CentOS 7.5.  I'm seeing this on my dev machines and in the testbed.  The hazard here is that all tasks will be identified as locally-originating, and that effectively bypasses the stock limit configuration.

Not sure why Pete's limits aren't making any identifications; will ask if it's stock.

title: Zombie Processes Blocking Database Operations
body:
Shawn McKee reported a problem where his database got blocked up by a query that ran an external program that wasn't properly reaped.  This caused something to remain locked and as a result pretty much every other query got stuck behind it.

Need to make sure that the Python library's `run_program()` deals with that properly.

ETA:

Looks like we need to add a `process.wait()` in these sections to clean them up:

https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/47078cbaac5212330eeeaa9c51f3eac23a0ee883/python-pscheduler/pscheduler/pscheduler/program.py#L274
https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/47078cbaac5212330eeeaa9c51f3eac23a0ee883/python-pscheduler/pscheduler/pscheduler/program.py#L319

title: Verify that plot-schedule works
body:
Plot-schedule seems to leave empty gaps where there should be schedule data.

Also doesn't seem to show non-starters where there probably should be some.

title: Filestring dies on empty string
body: The `filestring()` function in the Python library overshoots the end of an empty string when looking for a leading `@`.

title: Missing NUMA dependencies
body:
John Hicks bumped into a situation where iperf3 and nuttcp wouldn't run on Debian:
```
OSError: [Errno 2] No such file or directory: ‘numactl’
```

In the CentOS version, both tool plugins use `numactl` but neither depends on it.  It happens to work there because the test plugin depends on it but doesn't use it.

John's system also wound up with no `pscheduler-tool-iperf3` after installing `perfsonar-testpoint`, which it should have.

To do:

- [x] Fix on CenOS
- [ ] Fix on Debian

title: Exception from pscheduler-api "TypeError: 'NoneType' object is not iterable"
body:
Hello Mark,
As pointed in Slack:
My system is pS testpoint staging.
I see these exceptions pop up regularly every 1h.

It could be I am able to match them to a test. I will give a second post about it later.

```
Jul 16 11:02:24 t2-psdev pscheduler-api INFO     Denied fd10:1::2 POST https://test1.rrze/pscheduler/tasks

title: Fix log propagation and other anomalies
body:
During #597, I found some odd behaviors in how the `Log` class would change the environment variable that would pass state through for debugging child processes.

This was cleaned up and tagged for that issue, but we can wait for 4.1.1 or 4.2 to release the change.

The issue branch will be renamed to match this ticket; keep it open until we start development on 4.1.x and merge it into that branch.

Edit:  Renamed branch to [issue-644](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/tree/issue-644).

title: Result version mismatch when running reverse throughput
body:
On a production system:

```
[root@farm-host ~]# pscheduler task throughput --dest perfsonardev0.internet2.edu --reverse
Submitting task...
Task URL:
https://a1.ps.dev.internet2.edu/pscheduler/tasks/815093ab-0103-4dd0-b3ac-43a7bab3f7fb
Running with tool 'iperf3'
Fetching first run...

Next scheduled run:
https://a1.ps.dev.internet2.edu/pscheduler/tasks/815093ab-0103-4dd0-b3ac-43a7bab3f7fb/runs/e8d7ccff-fe75-4ba3-a4b1-2449bb20b6b7
Starts 2018-06-27T21:09:49-04:00 (~8 seconds)
Ends   2018-06-27T21:10:08-04:00 (~18 seconds)
Waiting for result...
Unable to retrieve formatted result: Failed to format result: At /summary/summary: Additional properties are not allowed (u'receiver-throughput-bits' was unexpected)

[root@farm-host ~]# rpm -q pscheduler-test-throughput pscheduler-tool-iperf3
pscheduler-test-throughput-1.0.2.6-1.el7.centos.noarch
pscheduler-tool-iperf3-1.0.2.6-1.el7.centos.noarch
```
At the other end (nightly):
```
[mfeit@perfsonardev0 ~]$ rpm -q pscheduler-test-throughput pscheduler-tool-iperf3
pscheduler-test-throughput-1.1-0.1.b1.el6.2103.a91094cda37134f752cc09ebf145ad502911a35e.noarch
pscheduler-tool-iperf3-1.1-0.1.b1.el6.2103.a91094cda37134f752cc09ebf145ad502911a35e.noarch
```

We may have to eliminate the extra field in the result until we figure out how to deal with old leads testing to second participants with newer firmware.  I'm thinking we may have to have the far end look at the schema version in the test spec and not burp out results with newer fields.

title: Local host name assumptions aren't always accurate

title: Remove Volatile Names from Unit Testing
body:
There are a number of instances in [unittesting.py](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/master/python-pscheduler/pscheduler/pscheduler/unittesting.py) that refer to hosts at ESNet which may or may not continue to exist.

Suggest adding some dummy hosts to the `perfsonar.net` zone that can be used for these tests that only require resolution of `A`, `AAAA` and `A`+`AAAA` hosts.

title: a latency non-starter task?
`pscheduler schedule` raises exception when trying to report bad usage
body:
This is a very minor bug, but I thought I would report it anyway. To reproduce:

```
$ pscheduler schedule +PT2H --host foo
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/commands/schedule", line 225, in <module>
    pscheduler.fail(usage)
NameError: name 'usage' is not defined
```

I guess it should be something like `pscheduler.fail(opt_parser.get_usage())`

This is from package `pscheduler-core-1.0.2.6-1.el6.noarch` from PS toolkit.

title: Adjust python-psycopg2 requirements.
body:
From Slack.  Need to make sure we're getting a version of psycopg2 where this functions correctly.

Looks like Marian had 2.5.1; he installed 2.6.1 and the problem went away.  My dev systems are getting 2.7.4 from PGDG.


-----
Marian Babik [8:32 AM]
hey, just finished debugging a centos7 toolkit instance that had this error:
safe_run/scheduler ERROR    Exception: ProgrammingError: syntax error at or near ")"
                                                            LINE 2: ...    FROM schedule_runs_to_schedule WHERE task in () LIMIT 50
turned out the system was using yum priorities and python-psycopg2 came from centos-base instead of internet2
this of course has messed up the entire installation, perhaps adding something on the expected priority of internet2 repo to the docs would help

Mark Feit [8:37 AM]
The maintainers strongly discourage use of priorities.  If anything, it's probably the RPM depending on python-psycopg2 and without specifying a version.

Marian Babik [8:37 AM]
so I understand pscheduler depends on python-psycopg2, right ?
let me look up the exact versions


Mark Feit [8:38 AM]
It does, yes.  The RPM that needs it requires >= 2.2.0.

Marian Babik [8:38 AM]
I had python-psycopg2-2.5.1-3.el7.x86_64 instead of python-psycopg2-2.6.1-1.rhel7.x86_64
after installing 2.6.1 and re-installing pscheduler the error went away
anyway, in case priorities are discouraged I would just add it to the docs (so people don't expect this to work) ....

Mark Feit [8:40 AM]
I'll check the versions of everything and adjust the RPM specs accordingly.

title: Replace calls to select() with poll()
body:
The PAS systems are experiencing problems where a call to `select()` in `run_program()` are failing because the file descriptor numbers are beyond the size of the bit set used internally.  This program demonstrates it:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python

import select

for fdcount in range(1,2000):
    fds = map(lambda x: open("/dev/null"), range(0,fdcount))
    print fds[-1]
    select.select([fds[-1]], [], [], 0.0001)
    for fd in fds:
        fd.close()
```

Game plan:

- [x] Develop a drop-in replacement for `select()` that uses `poll()`
- [x] Develop unit tests
- [x] Replace all uses of `select()` with the new version

title: Improve restore diagnostics
body:
The restore process doesn't produce sufficient diagnostic output when one part of the process fails, ~~often as a result of the issue in #579~~.

See this thread for details:  https://lists.internet2.edu/sympa/arc/perfsonar-user/2018-02/msg00041.html

title: Detect and clean up root-owned PID files
body:
Older installations may have left root-owned PID files in `/var/run` that cause permission problems during restarts and stops.

Add some code to the RPM spec or the start/stop scripts to hunt those down and remedy the problem.

title: Bulk AS resolver doesn't handle empty list properly
body:
Casey Russell reported seeing this in the logs:

```
Feb 21 07:55:18 ps-fhsu-bw journal: runner INFO     12356773: Run failed 1: Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/commands/../classes/tool/traceroute/run", line 389, in <module>
    ases = pscheduler.as_bulk_resolve(ips, threads=len(ips))
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/site-packages/pscheduler/psas.py", line 76, in as_bulk_resolve
    processes=min(len(candidates), threads))
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 714, in __init__
    Pool.__init__(self, processes, initializer, initargs)
  File "/usr/lib64/python2.7/multiprocessing/pool.py", line 152, in __init__
    raise ValueError("Number of processes must be at least 1")
ValueError: Number of processes must be at least 1
```

This looks to be a case where the traceroute produced no entries and the AS resolver tried to set up a pool of threads with zero entries.

The solution is to make `as_bulk_resolve()` quit early if the list of hosts is empty.

Also check the bulk DNS resolver for the same thing.

title: Allow Missed -> Failed Transition
body: On rare occasions, a run will be declared missed and then come in as failed.  Add this to the table of valid transitions in `run_state`.

title: Runner loses connection to PostgreSQL
body:
Periodically on my development VMs (and _only_ there), I'll start the system up and have the runner lose its connection to the database because the database thinks it send an invalid message.

This may be a thread safety problem.

title: Backup fails on systems with Pg 8.x installed
body:
The backup script uses `pg_dump ... --serializable-deferrable`, which isn't present in Pg 8.x, which is installed on some systems and in the default path.

Need to find a way to run the right one across all distributions.  (The alternatives mechanism may come into play here.)

title: pscheduler overlapping exclusive tests
body:
We recently upgraded I2's internal pS instance that it uses to measure its backbone connections. Most of the time everything looks good, but periodically (about once a day) we have a rolling failure across the board where throughput test results get poor. After about 1 poor result, things recover until the next day.

Doing some digging, I found an example in the output of one host. Below is the "schedule" output trimmed to the two offending tests. Note the overlapping timeframes. As expected, test 1 performance starts off high and gets bad at the end, and test 2 starts off bad and gets high at the end, ie both are bad only during the overlap period.

This is a pretty aggressive mesh. We are doing throughput tests every hour and each host is involved in a lot of tests. I only mention this because it may be an edge case in the scheduler when things are close together. It also seems to line up roughly with when meshconfig adds the next set of tests, but I can't confirm that 100%.

Andy suggested that this may be a function of randomized slip being incorrectly calculated/applied. I am trying a few workarounds from him and will update the ticket if it seems to have a good effect.


> 2017-12-19T12:05:34Z - 2017-12-19T12:06:03Z  (Finished)
> throughput --omit PT5S --duration PT20S --source 10.13.0.169 --dest 10.13.0.170 --window-size 96000000 --parallel 1 (Run with tool 'iperf3')
> https://localhost/pscheduler/tasks/cdbb9dd2-2a2f-41c0-9710-abcd465a1b8e/runs/e3acb563-5c7c-4ffa-bc31-c8d1d34ce925
>

title: Make SSL Warnings into Exceptions
body:
**This is not urgent and won't be an issue when we make the shift to Python 3.**

The `requests` library balks under certain circumstances (notably when there's an old version of pyOpenSSL on the system) and produces a warning on the standard error.  For long-running programs that make multiple requests, the pipe back to the parent process eventually backs up and the process stops.

Need to capture the warnings and prevent the writes, preferably turning them into an exception or HTTP error code.  There are some useful ideas here:  https://github.com/requests/requests/issues/2214

Also consider whether we want to stay with requests or switch to libcurl.

title: Changes to pg_hba.conf aren't atomic
body:
The alteration of PostgreSQL's `pg_hba.conf` in the pscheduler-server spec operates on the file in place.  A failure can result in that file being missing or empty, disabling the server.

Consider either a revision to [drop-in](https://github.com/markfeit/drop-in) that makes in-place editing atomic by writing to another file and moving it or handle it in the RPM spec.  The former would be preferable.

title: Expanded tasks don't come with an href
body: Fetching `/tasks?expanded`  or `/tasks/xxx` doesn't include an HREF.

title: Treat NULL Community Strings as Invalid
body: If `_community` is `null`, the library underpinning the SNMP tools balks.  The test needs to treat `null` as invalid.

title: CVE-2017-9798 Breaks PUTs
body:
RedHat's fix for [CVE-2017-9798](https://access.redhat.com/security/cve/CVE-2017-9798) breaks pScheduler's ability to serve `POST` and `DELETE` requests unimpeded.

@arlake228 The version number hasn't been touched.  I'll let you decide what to do with it.

Downstream:  This wlll probably affect you, too.

**Release Notes:**

Added pScheduler-specific verb limits to eliminate problems caused by OS vendor fix for CVE-2017-9798.

title: File Getting Left Open
body:
Marian Babik observed this:

```
Sep 11 15:25:36 perfsonar-lt safe_run/ticker ERROR    Restarting
Sep 11 15:25:36 perfsonar-lt safe_run/ticker ERROR    Program threw an exception after 0:00:00.002590
Sep 11 15:25:36 perfsonar-lt safe_run/ticker ERROR    Exception: IOError: [Errno 24] Too many open files: '/etc/pscheduler/database/database-dsn'#012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/saferun.py", line 41,
in safe_run#012    function()#012  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/ticker", line 153, in <lambda>#012    pscheduler.safe_run(lambda: main_program())#012  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/ticker", line 123, in main_program#012    db = pscheduler.pg_
connection(dsn)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/db.py", line 28, in pg_connection#012    dsn = string_from_file(dsn)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/filestring.py", line 24, in string_from_file#012    with open(pat
h, 'r') as content:#012IOError: [Errno 24] Too many open files: '/etc/pscheduler/database/database-dsn'
Sep 11 15:25:36 perfsonar-lt safe_run/ticker ERROR    Waiting 60.0 seconds before restarting
```

Looks like the problem is too many Unix-domain sockets being open, probably as connections to PostgreSQL.

A better way to solve this would be for `safe_run` to re-exec the program and find a way to pickle and pass its state data through the environment like the logger does.

    oid_list = spec['oid']
KeyError: 'oid'
```

This should require at least one OID.  Same probably goes for snmpgetbgm, too.

title: Don't clobber log rotation configs
body: Make the `python-pscheduler` RPM spec specify noreplace for the files that go into `/etc/logrotate.d` so custom configurations aren't overwritten on upgrade.

title: pSc-scheduler locked for locally initiated tasks: “never scheduled a run for the task”
body:
Problem:  there are seldom cases, where locally initiated tasks are not being scheduled.
Error message from CLI is: **“never scheduled a run for the task.”** (see below)
The weirdness about it is that the task is a single participant with local node as source and is a non-blocking one.
1. As an observation it is also appealing, that the task ID (generated by pSc at CLI) is not reported in the pSc.logs, unless the debug flag is used.
2. In a normal operation: the moment pSc generates a task ID and a run, there is an event in the pSc.log that signifies the creation of the task even without the debug flag.
3. Another observation is that remote participants are able to negotiate tests with the local host, through the API even during the "blocking" state. Their requests (task IDs ) are being reported in the pSc.log the moment they are run. 
4. Also pSc monitor operates fine and shows tasks as they stay in the scheduler and dynamically updates the status of those on the screen. Nevertheless there are no tasks from the local mesh configuration visible. 

**pscheduler task --debug rtt --dest es.net**
```

title: Trace tools generate bogus hostname records
body:
Seen in the result produced by the `tracepath` and `paris-traceroute`  tools:
```
                    {
                        "as": {
                            "number": 15083,
                            "owner": "INFOLINK-MIA-US - Infolink Global Corporation, US"
                        },        
                        "hostname": null,
                        "ip": "69.60.96.106",
                        "mtu": 1500,
                        "rtt": "PT0.036697S"
                    },
```

The `hostname` should not be present if it's null.

title: API lists plugins that aren't available
body:
Many (if not all) of the API endpoints that list or involve plugins (test, tool, archiver, context) use SELECTs that don't discard plugins that aren't available.

E.g.
```
SELECT json FROM xxx ORDER BY NAME
```
...needs to become...
```
SELECT json FROM xxx WHERE available ORDER BY NAME
```

title: Merged-results mishandles failures
body:
In some cases, the `merged-results` methods in tools are looking at the array of results unprotected from `None` values, e.g.:
```
succeeded = input['results'][0]['succeeded']
```

These should be changed to force a failure, possibly with an error message, e.g.:
```
try:
    succeeded = input['results'][0]['succeeded']
except (KeyError, TypeError):
    succeeded = False
```

title: Set no/long expiration when creating pscheduler account
body:
From [this comment](https://lists.internet2.edu/sympa/arc/perfsonar-user/2017-07/msg00007.html) in perfsonar-users.

- [x] See to it that the account never expires.
- [x] Use `chage` to force the password expiration off or very long.

title: Constraint violation during warm boot
body:
@vvidic Observed the following on Debian:

```
Jul  5 07:13:38 autopkgtest-lxc-gnzvcc safe_run/ticker ERROR    Exception: IntegrityError: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "test_name_key"
DETAIL:  Key (name)=(trace) already exists.
CONTEXT:  SQL statement "INSERT INTO test (json, updated, available)
      VALUES (new_json, now(), true)"
PL/pgSQL function test_upsert(jsonb) line 14 at SQL statement
SQL statement "SELECT test_upsert(test_enumeration)"
PL/pgSQL function test_boot() line 43 at PERFORM
SQL statement "SELECT test_boot()"
PL/pgSQL function warm_boot() line 4 at PERFORM
SQL statement "SELECT warm_boot()"
PL/pgSQL function cold_boot() line 3 at PERFORM

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/pscheduler/saferun.py", line 41, in safe_run
    function()
  File "/usr/lib/pscheduler/daemons/ticker", line 156, in <lambda>
    pscheduler.safe_run(lambda: main_program())
  File "/usr/lib/pscheduler/daemons/ticker", line 127, in main_program
    cursor.execute("SELECT cold_boot()")

IntegrityError: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "test_name_key"
DETAIL:  Key (name)=(trace) already exists.
CONTEXT:  SQL statement "INSERT INTO test (json, updated, available)
      VALUES (new_json, now(), true)"
PL/pgSQL function test_upsert(jsonb) line 14 at SQL statement
SQL statement "SELECT test_upsert(test_enumeration)"
PL/pgSQL function test_boot() line 43 at PERFORM
SQL statement "SELECT test_boot()"
PL/pgSQL function warm_boot() line 4 at PERFORM
SQL statement "SELECT warm_boot()"
PL/pgSQL function cold_boot() line 3 at PERFORM
```
Valentin's theory (probably correct) is that this is happening during an install or an upgrade where the ticker is starting up and doing a cold boot while other packages might be doing the same.

In theory, this shouldn't matter because it's all supposed to be wrapped in transactions.  Need to see if this can be reproduced and what the cause is.

title: Improve Affinity Handling for Unroutable Addresses
body: The [code in iperf3's run method](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/master/pscheduler-tool-iperf3/iperf3/run#L312) doesn't handle `(None, None)` being returned by `address_interface()` and will pass it through to `interface_affinity()`, which uses it blindly.

Looks like when determining the CPU affinity and looking up the interface it assumes AF_INET.

title: pscheduler task is not setting default slip
body: If you run `pscheduler task` at the command-line without a slip value, it will not fill-in a default. This leads to tasks being unable to find a timeslot of the exact start is not available.

title: pscheduler-scheduler needs restart after a few days
body: On pretty much all the ESnet hosts as far as I can tell, after a few days pscheduler-server seems to stop scheduling new runs and needs a restart. I have been waking up most mornings to 1 or 2 in this state, and it always appears to be different ones. As soon as you do the restart it starts scheduling new runs. So far I have been unable to find any errors in pscheduler.log, so i don't have much more information. I think a few people on the list have seen this as well and they've either rebooted or restarted the service and things have come back.

title: confirm that iperf3 retransmit info is captured correctly
body:
I'm seeing many plots like this where retransmits went away after the upgrade:

http://ps-dashboard.es.net/perfsonar-graphs/?url=http://hous-pt1.es.net:8085/esmond/perfsonar/archive&source=192.12.137.251&dest=198.129.254.50&url=http://hous-pt1.es.net:8085/esmond/perfsonar/archive&source=192.12.137.251&dest=198.129.254.66&#start=1490365406&end=1493043806&summaryWindow=3600&timeframe=1m

This might be due to some fix in CentOS 6.9, or might be due to a bug. Need to confirm all is working as expected.

    raise value
dns.name.EmptyLabel"
```

Looks like we're not catching the exception listed above.

title: Systemd isn't daemonizing daemons
body:
On CentOS 7, the [template used for systemd](https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/master/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/service-template.raw) doesn't use the `--daemon` switch when starting the daemons.  This results in the crash-proofing code in the daemons not being enabled and the process bombing out if it encounters a failure (PostgreSQL not being up in the observed case.)

To Do:

- [x] Add `--daemon` to `ExecStart`
- [x] Set up proper dependencies so Pg is started first.  (Optional; program will flail until it does.)

title: Remove repeat spec from ISO 8601 validator
body: In jsonval.py, the Duration validator includes `Rxxx` at the beginning.  That needs to go.

title: Don't export slip if using default
body: If the slip value wasn't specified on the `task` command line, don't export it.

body:
Adjust the requirement for the Python JSON Schema module to require at least 2.5.0.

Antoine observed this with Debian's 2.3.0:

title: Clear exec bits on daemon configurations.
body: The daemon configuration files in `/etc/pscheduler/daemons` are installed with the execution bits set.  Fix this.

body:
I'll dig into this, but just for the record...

    if test_result[succeeded_field]:
TypeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute '__getitem__'
```

title: nuttcp tool issues with dual stack hosts
body:
It was discovered today that nuttcp is not "just working" in the case of a host with dual stack networking. From Andy:

2) The nuttcp client looks like its defaulting to v6 when given a DNS name that has both A and AAAA, but the server is defaulting to IPv4 since we don't actually pass that an address to bind to
3) When we do specify ip-version its not getting passed to the nuttcp server, so it binds to the wrong place

This is very reminiscent of a similar issue in iperf3, so likely a similar solution.

title: RabbitMQ archiver doesn't work on EL6
body:
Jorge reports that the RabbitMQ archiver doesn't work on EL6 systems.

This was traced to the  `URLParameters` class not appearing until python-pika 0.9.8, and EPEL for EL6 supplies 0.9.5.  EPEL for EL7 provides 0.10.0.

title: Require API 1 on all REST endpoints
body:
All REST endpoints should have an `api` parameter that specifies the API version.  If not present, assume `1`.

Anything asking for anything later should get a 400 (bad request),  426 (upgrade required; this may not be appropriate) or 501 (not implemented)

Slightly related to #74.

title: localhost/non-FQDN host replacements in log returns
Check that post-test result gathering is properly bound.
body: Title says it all.

title: HTTP archiver retry policy not properly applied
body: The retry policy code in the HTTP archiver will only be run if the op is invalid.  That needs to happen when either the `POST` or `PUT` operations fails.

title: Parallelize the Scheduler
body:
Currently, the scheduler operates serially.  It was left this way to avoid situations where arrangements believed okay would become invalid, but it turns out that in #327 we saw it happen.

Threading the scheduler will avoid the kinds of jam-ups seen in #348.

title: Simplestreamer doesn't honor --source parameter
body:
(This is in 1.0 because it's a toy tool not critical for RC3.)

The simplestreamer tool needs to bind to whatever's in `--source`.

title: Partially-failed remote servers slowing scheduling
body:
This morning the UMich host was not answering queries in a timely manner (if at all) and the resulting drag was causing the scheduler to get way behind.

A ping of the web interface with a short timeout before trying to do anything meaningful would be a decent band-aid.

This is where partial parallelization of the scheduler might be a good thing.

title: Clean up url_* errors
body:
The `url_*` functions return error strings that look like this:
```
('Connection aborted.', error(99, 'Cannot assign requested address'))
```
Pick them apart and make them look like this:
```
Connection aborted: Cannot assign requested address
```

title: Monitor sometimes misses things
body:
There may be an off-by-one error in the monitor that causes it not to show the first future run.

This is sort of a cosmetic bug that can wait, so I'm not putting it in 1.0rc3.

title: BWCTL tool 'sum' Exceptions
body:
Seeing a few of these in the logs on perfsonardev0:
```
Mar  4 12:07:02 perfsonardev0 tool-bwctl/run ERROR    Exception 'sum'
```

From a quick grep through the sources, it looks like this is the `run` method in `pscheduler-tool-bwctliperf2/bwctliperf2` or `pscheduler-tool-bwctliperf2/bwctliperf3`, both of which register themselves as `tool-bwctl`.  (All of the methods in those tools do that; this should probably be fixed, too.)

The `Logger` class has a method called `exception()` that will send a full accounting of the last-thrown exception.  This is worth calling anytime you catch an exception you can't otherwise handle.

title: Handle scheduling conflicts gracefully
body:
The scheduler doesn't behave well when something sneaks in and grabs a time slot during processing.

This shouldn't be treated as an internal problem; the API should spit back an error indicating that it was unable to schedule the run and the scheduler should try again.  Anything previously scheduled will need to be removed.

From the logs:
```
Feb 24 15:19:17 perfsonardev0 pscheduler-api ERROR    Exception: InternalError: Run would result in a scheduling conflict.
CONTEXT:  SQL statement "WITH inserted_row AS (
        INSERT INTO run (uuid, task, times, state, errors)
        VALUES (run_uuid, task.id, time_range, initial_state, nonstart_reason)
        RETURNING *
    ) SELECT               uuid FROM inserted_row"
PL/pgSQL function api_run_post(uuid,timestamp with time zone,uuid,text) line 29 at SQL statement

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "./pschedulerapiserver/runs.py", line 395, in tasks_uuid_runs_run
  File "./pschedulerapiserver/dbcursor.py", line 107, in dbcursor_query
InternalError: Run would result in a scheduling conflict.
CONTEXT:  SQL statement "WITH inserted_row AS (
        INSERT INTO run (uuid, task, times, state, errors)
        VALUES (run_uuid, task.id, time_range, initial_state, nonstart_reason)
        RETURNING *
    ) SELECT               uuid FROM inserted_row"
PL/pgSQL function api_run_post(uuid,timestamp with time zone,uuid,text) line 29 at SQL statement

```

title: Allow more time to accumulate remote results
body:
The runner currently does one attempt to retrieve the results from the other participants.  The occasionally happens too fast and those results end up `null` when the test succeeded.

Restructure the loop after `Accumulated local result` so it retries results it doesn't have until everything has been retrieved or a timeout passes.

title: Runs don't always start in sync.
body:
(This is an "after-the-fact" ticket.)

Runs aren't always starting in sync.  This may be because the runner uses one database connection, and even though its individual cursors are thread-safe, they're probably getting serialized.

title: missing powstream processes. which service has to manage the problem?

There is no responsible service to monitor and maintain powstream processes. Since powstream processes are mostly/exclusively defined and triggered through the meshconfig-agent configuration, I would have expected the meshconfig-agent on each of its reoccurring configuration checks to verify the powstream processes based on the configuration in -tasks.conf. (As agreed on the call yesterday I am opening this ticket with pscheduler)

title: Investigate 500 return code on DELETE of task
body:
Need to look at why we return 500 on DELETE of a task that's not there.

Casually related to https://github.com/perfsonar/mesh-config/issues/55.

From Slack:

```
vvidic [6:19 AM] 
Feb  8 12:17:34 pstest pscheduler-api ERROR    Exception: InternalError: Task not found while disabling task d397050d-da75-43a9-bf5c-afb9854f3120#012CONTEXT:  PL/pgSQL function api_task_disable(uuid,text) line 12 at RAISE#012#012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/usr/share/pscheduler/api-server/pschedulerapiserver/dbcursor.py", line 97, in dbcursor_query#012    cursor.execute(query, args)#012InternalError: Task not found while disabling task d397050d-da75-43a9-bf5c-afb9854f3120#012CONTEXT:  PL/pgSQL function api_task_disable(uuid,text) line 12 at RAISE

[6:19]  
any way to clean up this task?

vvidic [6:25 AM] 
198.128.151.30 - - [08/Feb/2017:12:23:43 +0100] "DELETE /pscheduler/tasks/d397050d-da75-43a9-bf5c-afb9854f3120 HTTP/1.1" 500 1909 "-" "python-requests/2.4.3 CPython/2.7.9 Linux/3.16.0-4-amd64"

[6:25]  
maybe handle this rather than returning 500?

mfeit [7:41 AM] 
Not sure why that's happening.  The request is coming from the outside (presumably meshconfig), so the question would be why there's a difference between what MC and pSc think exists.  404 instead of 500 would be a better return for that.  I'll write a ticket on it.
```

title: Allow for clock slop in scheduling horizon
body:
The scheduler may be trying to schedule runs with participants where the start time is just outside the horizon because of clock errors.  Add some tolerance for that in `run_alter`.  Maybe make it configurable.

From Slack:

```
vvidic [9:27 AM] 
2017-02-08 15:26:49 CET [2644-1] pscheduler@pscheduler ERROR:  Cannot schedule runs more than 1 day in advance
2017-02-08 15:26:49 CET [2644-2] pscheduler@pscheduler CONTEXT:  PL/pgSQL function run_alter() line 37 at RAISE
       SQL statement "WITH inserted_row AS (
               INSERT INTO run (uuid, task, times, state, errors)
               VALUES (run_uuid, task.id, time_range, initial_state, nonstart_reason)
               RETURNING *
           ) SELECT               uuid FROM inserted_row"
       PL/pgSQL function api_run_post(uuid,timestamp with time zone,uuid,text) line 29 at SQL statement
2017-02-08 15:26:49 CET [2644-3] pscheduler@pscheduler STATEMENT:  SELECT api_run_post('3e3b01b6-71be-4bb5-a1ca-4c5acbe0f13e', '2017-02-09T15:34:10+01:00'::timestamptz, NULL, NULL)

[9:27]  
is this some kind of timezone problem?

[9:30]  
guess not as the date uses +0100

[9:31]  
it really was more than one day in advance at that point

mfeit [9:33 AM] 
All of the date calculations are done with timezone-aware types.

[9:35]  
Could also be that the clock on one of the machines is off just far enough that the run would be just outside the valid range.
```

title: Check that TTL-Expired Archivings are Removed from Pool
body: Verify that the periodic maintenance on the `archiving` table is turning on the `archived` bit when an archiving exceeds its TTL.

title: Random Slip not Random Enough
body:
Title says it all.

Andy observes that the code's not really complete:   https://github.com/perfsonar/pscheduler/blob/e029f9875aab638993fbaf82e21217749f3f871c/pscheduler-server/pscheduler-server/daemons/scheduler#L192

title: Latencybg spec-to-cli generates extra argument for --flip
body:
While doing #275, noticed that the `cli` field in the details for latencybg generates  `[..., "--flip", "True", ...]` when it should just generate `[..., "--flip", ...]`


```
{
    ...
    "detail": {
        ...
        "cli": [
            "--dest",
            "test-owamp1.es.net",
            "--packet-padding",
            "0",
            "--flip",
            "True",     <---------- This shouldn't be here
            "--source",
            "antg-staging.es.net",
            "--ip-version",
            "4",
            "--packet-interval",
            "0.1",
            "--duration",
            "PT86400S",
            "--packet-count",
            "600"
        ],
     ...
    },
    ...
}
```

title: Runner not ignoring disabled tests
body: I noticed on test-pt1.es.net that its continuing to run some tests that are no longer enabled. Example: https://test-pt1.es.net/pscheduler/tasks/a18413b8-9dee-43c1-8465-ece455d1a60f?detail=1 is running at the time of this issue creation. If I stop the pscheduler-runner the processes stop but when I start it again, the test fires up a new set of processes.

title: excessive runs?
body:
While looking through some of the throughput errors, I came across this observation:

Task spec:
https://ma-dev2.bldc.grnoc.iu.edu/pscheduler/tasks/5ccc9e0a-7950-4a0e-9e94-228a0c90708a/runs

Note it's a 24 hour task, 2 hour repeat interval

Runs listing:
https://ma-dev2.bldc.grnoc.iu.edu/pscheduler/tasks/5ccc9e0a-7950-4a0e-9e94-228a0c90708a/runs


There are a lot of runs. With the given slip I think you could expect up to around 16 possible runs in that timeframe, but we have way more than that listed here. A good number of them are listed as non-starters.

After talking with Mark, he asked that I file this issue on it. It's possible this is related to the throughput issues. We are also going to work on standing up some more multiparticipant tests to help troubleshoot this as well.

title: scheduled tests start to fail after a Limits change, with a fresh test, old tests (from sched) are again successful

title: Harmonize IP TOS Values
body:
@HakanCalimFau was seeing validation errors when trying to run `latency` with `--ip-tos 200005`.

IP TOS is not consistent in naming or how it's applied throughout the system.

| Test | How Named | How Defined |
|------|-------------|--------------|
| `latencybg` | `ip-tos` | `#/pScheduler/IPTOS` |
| `latency` | `ip-tos` | `#/pScheduler/IPTOS` |
| `rtt` | `tos` | `#/pScheduler/Cardinal` |
| `throughput` | `tos` | `#/pScheduler/Cardinal` |
| `trace` | `tos` | `#/pScheduler/Cardinal` |


[RFC 2474, Section 3](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2474) defines an 8-bit number with 6 bits allotted for the DSCP field, giving valid values of `0` to `63`.  This is how `IPTOS` is defined in the JSON dictionary. 

Some programs (`ping`) expect the full DSFD byte; others are ambiguous.  Need to find out what's more common and make the `IPTOS` definition reflect that.

This is further complicated by some tools using this value as the IPv6 traffic control value.  Better to make `tos` and `tc` separate and complain if they're used in the wrong context.

title: Protect tasks/runs from undesired meddling
body:
(Not really a bug, but something that needs to be handled.)

Deny any API request that does writes other than POSTing a new task which doesn't come from the local host or the host that originally submitted the task.  This would include, but is not limited to:

 * Deleting (disabling) tasks
 * Adding runs
 * Deleting runs

In general, anything other than tasks with a `POST`, `PUT` or `DELETE` method needs to be considered.
