title: daemon file descriptor leak
body:
I noticed today on ma-dev2.bldc the following in /var/log/messages

> Dec 12 15:34:09 ma-dev2.bldc.grnoc.iu.edu safe_run/ticker ERROR    Exception: IOError: [Errno 24] Too many open files: '/etc/pscheduler/database/database-dsn'#012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/saferun.py", line 41, in safe_run#012    function()#012  File "/usr/l
> ibexec/pscheduler/daemons/ticker", line 100, in <lambda>#012    pscheduler.safe_run(lambda: main_program())#012  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/ticker", line 69, in main_program#012    db = pscheduler.pg_connection(dsn)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/db.py", line 25, in pg_connection#012    dsn = string_from_file(dsn)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/filestring.py", line 22, in string_from_file#012    with open(string[1:], 'r') as content:#012IOError: [Errno 24] Too many open files: '/etc/pscheduler/database/database-dsn'

Diving into it, it looks like that process has 1024 file descriptors which was the default ulimit settings on that machine. After restarting the process, the file descriptors went down to around 10 or so but occasionally would rise coincident with this in the logs:

> Dec 12 15:42:13 ma-dev2.bldc.grnoc.iu.edu safe_run/scheduler ERROR    Exception: ConnectionError: ('Connection aborted.', error(101, 'Network is unreachable'))#012Traceback (most recent call last):#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/saferun.py", line 41, in safe_run#012    function()#012  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler", line 453, in <lambda>#012    pscheduler.safe_run(lambda: main_program())#012  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler", line 409, in main_program#012    run_post(url, trynext, log)#012  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler", line 166, in run_post#012    r = requests.get(runtime_url, params=range_params, verify=False)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 68, in get#012    return request('get', url, **kwargs)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 50, in request#012    response = session.request(method=method, url=url, **kwargs)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 464, in request#012    resp = self.send(prep, **send_kwargs)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 576, in send#012    r = adapter.send(request, **kwargs)#012  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/adapters.py", line 415, in send#012    raise ConnectionError(err, request=request)#012ConnectionError: ('Connection aborted.', error(101, 'Network is unreachable'))

It seems like there may be some error being trapped but is leaving a filehandle open uncleanly.

title: `pscheduler internal reset` fails on Debian
body: `pscheduler internal reset` fails on Debian because it cannot find the `postgresql-load` command. This is installed by the postgresql-load package Mark built for pScheduler. I believe it was never ported to Debian because it is doing its own DB setup. We should either port it or find a way to make `pscheduler internal reset` work without it.

body:

creation, skipping test: 400 BAD REQUEST: At /source: u'2620:f:0:914::3' is not a 'host-name'
```
Need to adjust the code in `jsonval.py` so it takes IPv6 IPs as well.

title: latencybg runs not getting archived
body: After the most recent update it appears that runs from latencybg tasks are not getting archived. Other test types seem to work correctly. As far as I can tell, the latencybg runs are not even getting in the archiving database table. You can recreate by doing something like `pscheduler task --archive {...} latencybg --dest anl-owamp.es.net -t 120`.

title: logging.handlers.SysLogHandler.LOG_FTP does not exist on CentOS 6
body: pscheduler will not build on CentOS 6 because it can't find logging.handlers.SysLogHandler.LOG_FTP. Readong the python 2.6. docs it should be in there, but in fact it looks like SysLogHandlers is generated from a syslog.h file somewhere and for whatever reason the stock version that ships with CentOS 6 is missing this facility. Should be an easy fix to check these facilities with hasattr. I'll assign to myself and have a fix committed shortly.

title: Archiving needs to be parallelized
body:
The current implementation of the archiver daemon does one archive at a time, which causes problems on high-load systems.

Re-work it so it uses threads to parallelize the process.

title: Adjust Flask/Jinja2/Werkzeug package names
body:
The above were packaged for CentOS 6 and followed Red Hat's convention that the case match the upstream author's preference.

CentOS 7 added Jinja2 as `python-jinja2`, which conflicts with ours.  Because of that and Debian's all-lowercase convention:
 * Change the names of `python-Flask`, `python-Jinja2` and `python-Werkzeug` to lowercase.
 * Disable build of Jinja2 on CentOS 7

title: Need to periodically do a VACUUM ANALYZE in the database.
body:
Title says it all.

Need to find a nice way to do it inside a function, because you can't do it directly.

title: Monitor shouldn't pull the entire schedule
body:
This causes problems on heavily-loaded systems.

Optimize this by pulling everything running now, at most a screenful of runs in the past and at most a screenful of runs in the future.

title: move *_cmd to run
body: The $tool_cmd variable right now from the config is read at participant data time and passed down to the run methods. This means that a malicious pscheduler server could instruct participants to run arbitrary binaries. This needs to move out of particpant data and into run so that each instance looks its own information up for the path to the binary.

title: Check that hour matching in runschedule limit works
body: Been seeing a couple of instances where the hour for this limit doesn't work.  Investigate this.

title: Constraint violation when submitting a task
body:
Danny Lee spotted this:

title: Powstream producing bogus output
body:
Szymon observed this error from powstream.   Looks like it's printing a `None` someplace where it shouldn't and that's making the JSON invalid.

```
Oct 20 11:04:57 localhost journal: runner WARNING  Discarding bogus result None#012{"diags": null, "error": "powstream returned an error on startup, attempting restart after waiting 30 seconds: ", "succeeded": false, "schema": 1}
```

title: Run often takes longer than 30 seconds to schedule
body: On both antg-dev.es.net and antg-staging.es.net I frequently run into cases where I run something on the command-line and it takes longer than the 30 seconds for the first run to get scheduled. This was a problem because the CLI would only wait up to 30 sec for the run to get scheduled before exiting. I recently bumped this to 60 so we'll see how that does. The hosts are both running other tests and somewhat loaded, so that may contribute. I don't usually see it on clean dev hosts, but the hosts I am seeing it on are much more representative of the type of setup we'll see in the wild.

title: RTT task and hostname as source parameter
body:
RTT task promises that it accepts hostnames as source parameter. The output of `psc task rtt -help`:

```
task rtt --source ps2.example.org --dest ps.example.com
Measure round trip time from ps2.example.org to www.example.com
```

What is really happening is when using ping as tool for rtt (which is the default) `--source` parameter is translated to `-I` parameter which accepts only interface names or IP addresses.

title: Make trace and rtt background-ish tasks
body: An average perfsonar host runs trace (possibly tracepath) tasks every 10 minutes. This can make the schedule look pretty busy for throughput tasks since they want nothing running except background tasks (i.e. powstream) at the moment. Throughput tests should similarly ignore trace and rtt tasks since they have little to no impact on the results. Per discussion with Mark, it probably means a new test class since the current "background" tasks have some other characteristics, but should not be too difficult to implement.

title: `psc debug on` possibly not working on all scripts
body:
There are a handful of scripts that don't appear to have their debug environment passed in correctly from an invocation of `psc debug on`. I don't have a full list, but at least $test/`participants` seems to be affected.

Making the following change as an example:

```
--- a/pscheduler-test-throughput/throughput/participants
+++ b/pscheduler-test-throughput/throughput/participants
@@ -12,8 +12,12 @@ import sys
 logger = pscheduler.Log(prefix='test-throughput')
+logger.info("****************************INSIDE PARTICIPANTS INFO")
+logger.debug("****************************INSIDE PARTICIPANTS DEBUG")
+
```

and issuing a `psc debug on` and then starting a throughput test yields in /var/log/messages:

```
Oct 12 10:24:46 ps-test1 ticker DEBUG    Next check in 14 seconds
Oct 12 10:24:46 ps-test1 test-throughput/participants INFO     Started
Oct 12 10:24:46 ps-test1 test-throughput/participants INFO     Started
Oct 12 10:24:46 ps-test1 test-throughput/participants INFO     ****************************INSIDE PARTICIPANTS INFO
Oct 12 10:24:46 ps-test1 test-throughput/participants INFO     ****************************INSIDE PARTICIPANTS INFO
Oct 12 10:24:46 ps-test1 tool-iperf3/can-run INFO     Started
```

Note the lack of the "INSIDE PARTICIPANTS DEBUG" despite being in debug mode.

This isn't a priority for the RC since it mostly affects developers at this point, but would be good to fix up since it might afford us better field debugging opportunities in the future.

title: Error querying detailed task

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

title: Bulletproof Warmboot/Enumeration

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
Andy ran into a situation where a tool's directory remained but its contents had been wiped out.  The warmboot process complained bitterly about it each time it ran.

Consider making it quietly not enumerate anything without an `enumerate` method.  Maybe log it instead.

title: Make schedule paramaters offset-aware
body: The `schedule` program will take a timestamp that's offset-naive.  If these are provided, put them into the system's default time offset.

title: Re-Installed Test/Tools Don't Become Available
body: When a test or tool is uninstalled and later reinstalled, the record in the database isn't updated to show that it's available.  This is probably a bug in warmboot.

title: Make password strings very safe

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
An upgrade of `pscheduler-server`, which changes the database password each time, produced a password that tripped up one of the login mechanisms, which read it incorrectly and resulted in a login failure.

Adjust `random-string` so it can produce strings that don't contain characters likely to be misinterpreted in password files, DSNs, etc.

title: Runner waits for children but does not send signal to them on shutdown
body:
The best way to recreate this is to create a long-running powstream test. Once it's started, send a SIGTERM to the runner process (this used to be all that the init script did until I implemented a workaround that sends a SIGKILL after a few seconds):
`kill $(cat /var/run/pscheduler-runner.pid)`

Notice that the runner, run and powstream commands are all still running. Also notice the pid file is unlocked so new runners can start. This can lead to an explosion in processes if you have lots of long-running tests. Doing a few straces, the runner is blocking on some mysterious futex. It looks like maybe something is hijacking the atexit in the runner, because as far as I can tell, run_program should be set-up to send all the signals needed. 

I have worked-around this for now by adding the SIGKILL to the inits and some extra checks to powstream, but we should eventually figure out what is going on and get this right.

title: Handle Unschedulable Runs
body:
The change made in 7b66646cd0b644bff141951146fa07deec5268d8 appears to have been causing a scheduling jam up.

Try breaking out of the loop on error and doing it afterward with the original cursor.

This needs to be handled because if a planned run doesn't get scheduled, the scheduler will continue trying to schedule it repeatedly.  Shouldn't be too big an issue during RCs, but it will be in production.

title: Postrun doesn't work when url_get() is called
body:
Postrun.py has call to `url_get()` that makes the whole scheduling process fail.  The equivalent code that uses the `requests` module works fine when pasted in.  That has been left there in the interest of getting RC1 out the door, but this should be fixed.

The only thing I can think of is that this is the only place where the GET parameters have special characters because they have timestamps.

Also:  The code should probably also be moved into the scheduler, since it's the only thing that calls it and every other python program in the system doesn't need to be importing it.

title: Make sure local errors are merged

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
Local errors aren't being merged into `result_full`.  Should have diags brought across so the user can see something.

"synchronized": false}]
```

title: Make pscheduler-server RPM fail when postgresql-load does
body:
The calls to `postgresql-load` in the `pscheduler-server` RPM spec cause the scriptlet to stop on error, but for some internal, RPM-related reason, the whole operation continues.

Discussion:
- https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=569930
- https://marc.info/?l=rpm-devel&m=131843439324890&w=2  (Whole thread)
- ~~http://rpm5.org/community/rpm-users/0834.html~~  (Dead link)

Try to find a workaround for this.

title: Watch needs to linger longer
body:
The `watch` command doesn't always linger long enough for the next run to be scheduled.

Need to figure out how to deal with that given that there will be one-shots and repeaters.  Maybe query the task and look at the run count and end time.

title: Make throughput --omit take ISO8601

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body: This switch should be a standard time like everything else.

DataError: invalid input syntax for type json
DETAIL:  The input string ended unexpectedly.
CONTEXT:  JSON data, line 1:
PL/pgSQL function run_alter() line 154 at assignment
```

title: Post non-starter run for runs that can't be scheduled
body:
In the scheduler and `postrun.py`, consider posting a non-starting run with errors for any run that fails to schedule and is within the scheduler's refresh interval of happening.

This will allow the scheduler to keep retrying but not thrash about when runs don't end up on the timeline.  Also makes for better end-user diagnostics.

title: Scheduler throws exception

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
The scheduler has been seen throwing this exception:

```
Aug  1 14:13:15 dev9 safe_run/scheduler ERROR    Exception: MissingSchema: Invalid URL u"global name 'cursor' is not defined\n": No schema supplied. Perhaps you meant http://global name 'cursor' is not defined?
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/saferun.py", line 41, in safe_run
    function()
  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler", line 127, in <lambda>
    pscheduler.safe_run(lambda: main_program())
  File "/usr/libexec/pscheduler/daemons/scheduler", line 119, in main_program
    pscheduler.run_post(url, trynext, log)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/postrun.py", line 226, in run_post
    pscheduler.url_delete_list(runs_posted)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/psurl.py", line 144, in url_delete_list
    return [ url_delete(url, throw=False) for url in urls ]
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/pscheduler/psurl.py", line 128, in url_delete
    request = requests.delete(url, verify=verify_keys)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 146, in delete
    return request('delete', url, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/api.py", line 50, in request
    response = session.request(method=method, url=url, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 450, in request
    prep = self.prepare_request(req)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/sessions.py", line 381, in prepare_request
    hooks=merge_hooks(request.hooks, self.hooks),
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 304, in prepare
    self.prepare_url(url, params)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/requests/models.py", line 361, in prepare_url
    "Perhaps you meant http://{0}?".format(url))

MissingSchema: Invalid URL u"global name 'cursor' is not defined\n": No schema supplied. Perhaps you meant http://global name 'cursor' is not defined
```

And a similar one:

```
MissingSchema: Invalid URL u"global name 'psycopg2' is not defined\n": No schema supplied. Perhaps you meant http://global name 'psycopg2' is not defined
```

These are happening during a call to delete a URL, so it's possible that the URL `post_run` is getting back is wrong because of an error.

title: Make cli-to-spec output cleaner

milestone.title: 1.0rc1

body:
`cli-to-spec`  in all test types uses the generic `optparse` error output, which doesn't look good when passed back to a client.

Need to do an override of the `error()` method that just spits out the problem.

title: Inaccurate throughput participant selection

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
When trying to task...

```
dev8% pscheduler task throughput --source dev9
```

The server barfs with...

```
Unable to post task: Error while tasking 1@10.0.2.15: Unable to post task to 10.0.2.15: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "task_uuid_key"
DETAIL:  Key (uuid)=(74468e74-e8c4-4d5b-9ec1-c16ccb6d0be3) already exists.
CONTEXT:  SQL statement "WITH inserted_row AS (
        INSERT INTO task(json, participant, uuid, hints)
        VALUES (task_package, participant, task_uuid, hints)
        RETURNING *
    ) SELECT               * from inserted_row"
PL/pgSQL function api_task_post(jsonb,jsonb,integer,uuid) line 6 at SQL statement
```

This suggests that it's trying to task the same host twice when no `--dest` is specified and the `--source` is a remote host.

This works:

```
dev8% pscheduler task throughput --source dev9 --dest dev8
```

title: Use POST for test results.
body:
While implementing parallel flows for the iperf tools, it looks like I have run into a URI limit while sending back the test output. It's quite a lot of output.

Looking through the apache logs and talking with Mark quickly, it sounds like we are using "PUT" requests here, which have a URI limit of ~8k characters. We should convert this to using "POST" since the limit there is significantly higher and arguably is more correct in the REST model.

In particular this was the results coming out of "run" I think, but it might be worth checking out any other places we may expect there to be large-ish arbitrary data coming out of things.

title: Fix scheduling race condition
body:
In cases where one participant is slow, the test time comes up before the per-participant data can be populated and a tool trying to use it barfs.  (Need more graceful behavior on the tools' part when this happens.)

Need a better way to interlock run setup so all data can be properly set up before the run is scheduled.  This is kind of chicken-and-egg because you don't know how long that's going to take, which makes deciding on the time impossible.  May have to do a run time stretch and trim it back later.

The scheduler has an offset that was reduced from `PT10S` to `PT5S` in 689af65.  This will be put back to `PT10S` for the time being.

milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body: Title says it all.

title: Need CLI to stop a task.

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
Need to be able to:
- Stop a run that's already running
- Stop any further execution of a task

For the time being, the REST API should probably only allow this from the local host or maybe the IP that requested it.

title: Scheduler needs to schedule out to time horizon

milestone.title: 1.0rc1
milestone.description: First release candidate, coincides with TechEx 2016

body:
The scheduler doesn't continue scheduling runs until the time horizon.

This means that a task with tight repeats (e.g. `--repeat PT15S` doesn't get all of its runs scheduled until the scheduler has looped that many times.

title: Task and Watch Improvements
body:
Need to make the `task` command hand watching the run(s) off to `watch`.

Fix `watch` so it will dump out errors for non-starters.

Semi-related to #28

title: Improve handling of unschedulable tasks
body:
When starting a test from the CLI (or anywhere, actually), the default slip is `P0D`.  If there's another test running, the scheduler doesn't schedule it because there's no time slot.

To fix:
- ~~Need a default slip for the CLI.  Also should make a note that applications using the REST interface need to supply this, even for one-shot tasks.~~  (Fixed in 7b77181)
- ~~Need the notion of a stillborn run with a diagnostic so it can be fetched and dumped instead of the "Run on server was never populated" error.  (See `pscheduler-core/pscheduler-core/task:363`.)~~  (This has been taken care of.)
- CLI should remove tasks that don't get run.

Do that.  Soon.

title: CentOS 7 Things to Do
body:
Pick init.d/systemd in these packages: 
- scheduler-api-server
- pscheduler-tool-simplestreamer
- httpd-wsgi-socket

All are believed to do the right thing because there's init.d compatibility in CentOS 7.
